I was disappointed in Shadowrun Returns. I bought the title because I am a big fan of turn-based strategy games. However, what I ended up getting was not everything I was hoping it would be. But long story short, I'd still recommend the title, but only if the entire complete version cost you $7.50 or less. (That includes the Dragonfall expansion, the music, etc.) If I knew what I know now, I'd only pay $4.99 for Shadowrun Returns, complete edition.  That said, I would recommend the game only because it is what you will like in terms of turn-based stategy gaming. I am sure there are better titles out there in this genre (I want to try out XCOM some day), so I will have to go looking for them. But I dropped $11.97 for all the Shadowrun stuff when it went on sale. I believe that I paid double what it was worth, sadly.  The things that frustrate the heck out of me regarding Shadowrun Returns are the following:  * The melee animations are atrocious. If you run up and swing your sword on an enemy, it will look slow and akward. It truly makes me wonder if the developer tested this out or not - very poor presentation.  * Get used to seeing the word 'Missed' a lot. After having played through the Seattle campaign ('Dead Man's Switch'), I came to learn that there are not enough Karma (experience) points to go around. That means that you will need to specialize and forego any benefits outside your speciality. For example, I wanted to have all the conversation options available to me, so I built up for Decking and Charisma. But then I put into Quickness so that I could use a gun. Long story short, the highest I think I needed Charisma and Intelligence/Decking was 5. And even though I put a few more into them, I couldn't hit crap with my gun. Worse is when you hire mercenaries and they can't hit bad guys, either. It's like the developer wanted to make the ability to land hits on enemies a challenge, though it is very frustrating.  * The music was an add-on purchase for me (part of an upgraded bundle). I have to say, I was ripped off. It should have been included for free.  * Also, I ran into a few bugs in the Seattle campaign. One of them was the inability to act in the Universal Brotherhood scene when we were trying to rescue Marie. Some buttons could be clicked, but no one moved. I had to reset before it locked up again (recalling the autosave).  * One feature I would have loved would have been the ability to save my character from the Seattle campaign and then bring it over to the Berlin one. Then I could keep leveling him up, so to speak. But that is not available here.  * Lastly, while not a super-huge deal, this is a text-intensive video game. Basically, it plays like a graphic novel/comic book. So the graphics and the music and the gameplay are really just supposed to lend to storyline. I suppose everything does as intended. But there are so many typos, especially towards the end of the campaign, that I was hoping the developer would find somebody in the studio to just sit down and remove them all. Just polish the thing up. But like I said, not a super-huge deal. Just reminds me of the poor melee animations, which makes it seem like the developer did not care as much for this game as I, a paying customer, do.  So if you are up for reading a game, Shadowrun Returns is of that genre. And believe me - you are going to read! There are 'pathways' in communication here: one decision you make in a conversation can lead to a different path in that conversation. However, I have noticed that all the pathways really only lead to one end result nearly all of the time. That is, it doesn't matter on what you click. If you want to be a smart-♥♥♥ character or a polite one or whatever, there are sometimes options for each. But these by and large do not affect the storyline hardly at all. There may be a few exceptions, such as deciding the fate of an antagonist. However, like I said, no matter what you choose, it is going down the same railroad. Again, this is not a huge deal, especially since this is basically just an electronic comic book. But just know what you are getting here.  As far as character customization goes, it is a bit limited. The bigger problem is that you are probably not going to build a truly useful character. If you specialize, then hope that your hired mercenaries will do their jobs. Of course, that usually means that you don't need a Summoner, healer, or a multi-class guy. (I did the whole campaign without anything but ranged attackers by my side. At Decking level 5, I did all that Matrix stuff. The only thing I missed out on were all the locked doors.) But, really, if all you want to do is kill guys, that might be the better build. (Beware of 'Missed'!).  So to close, I simply restate that Shadowrun Returns is worth about $7.50 or less for the full, complete package. The only benefit to it seems to be the ability to make your own 'maps' (scenes) and build your own campaign. However, this game does not seem to have a boatload of features, so you would probably just be making your own video game comic book, then - like writing your own graphic novel. I don't know how fun that will be for you, but all I can say is that this entire game package is not worth very much money. I will search better turn-based games, and I will regret having dropped so much cash on Shadowrun Returns. Oh, and I will say that the developer's story is a creative one.

Pros/Cons  + Cool world and lore + Decent visuals and soundtrack + Noir-style storyline + Large number of player customization and play style options + Simple, easy to learn tactical combat system  - Linear and short, very little player choice in how the game progresses - Characters are likable but shallow and onenote - Story takes a turn for the ridiculous in the last act - Overly simple tactical combat, too easy - Broken cover and accuracy systems - Dragonfall, the far superior standalone DLC, can be bought for the same price  This is my first experience with the world of Shadowrun, but it’s easy to understand why it’s so popular. It’s a unique mix of gritty cyberpunk and whimsical fantasy, mechanically enhanced soldiers and mages, futuristic hackers and magical elves. It’s a weird combination, but it works. There’s a cool world here worth exploring, enhanced with atmospheric, if unmemorable, visuals and music. Unfortunately, the gameplay and story don’t quite do it justice.  This is an old-style isometric turn-based RPG, and it’s about as simple as they come. Battles are simple, your team versus a host of enemy goons, and consistently satisfying to complete. But battles are also small and take place mostly in linear corridors. With a cover system that appears useless and an accuracy system that rarely makes sense (my characters have missed shots that the system rated as having a 95% chance and above far too often), the tactics rarely amount to anything more than who can hit/stab/shoot/burn the hardest.  The game has a large number of classes, races, etiquettes, weapons, armors, and cyberware to choose from, but in combat, they all play very similarly, and the differences are mostly aesthetic. The variety is great, but it’s too bad that variety never translates into a difference in gameplay. The linear progression, lack of choice or sidequests, and similarity between classes means there is little to no replay value.  The story starts off well. It’s a basic noir-style murder mystery, held up more by the strength of its setting more than its writing, but it’s nonetheless compelling enough to carry the gameplay. It progresses standard enough, with the player following leads, interviewing suspects, battling bloodthirsty gangs, up until a certain point towards the end when the game takes a dramatic turn for the silly, and then an even more dramatic turn for the ludicrous. It remains compelling, but suspension of disbelief is broken and never repaired. You’ll meet a wide cast of characters who are for the most part likable and interesting, but lack depth, which is representative of the game’s overall problem.  It lacks depth. It has a cool setting, but that’s never satisfyingly explored. It’s a got large variety of classes and equipment, but which mostly play the same. It has decent gameplay, but it’s overly simple and linear.   But the game is also cheap, and worth a purchase if you can find it one sale. If you’re a fan of the Shadowrun universe or simple tactical RPG games, you’ll likely enjoy this. If you’re looking for something with more depth, that’s more open, with a better storyline, you should look elsewhere and be willing to spend more.  The most damning criticism of all is that you can buy the standalone DLC, Shadowrun: Dragonfall, which is an enormous improvement over this game in every facet, for the same price. There is no reason to recommend Returns over the far superior Dragonfall, which is more open, has a better storyline and characters, and better tactical combat. The developers improved so many things in Dragonfall they made Returns obsolete.

I bought this game specifically because I had heard that Shadowrun Dragonfall was such a good game and this was first in the series. After reading reviews about the rough edges of Returns I wasn't expecting much but to my surprise I found myself really enjoying this title. Everything negative you've heard about SR is true but despite the negatives the game is still tremendous fun. The game combines the CyberPunk fiction of a William Gibson or Neil Stephenson (including a little fantasy thrown in for kicks) with the turn-based RPG combat of the early Fallout or Jagged Alliance games. Shadowrun Returns certainly has its flaws but this little game is absolutely worth the ride! 7/10  Pros + Writing - Some of the writing is a bit rough but overall they really captured the cyberpunk vibe well + Turn-based Combat is superb and reminds me a lot of the original Fallout games + RPG Elements are really strong and it is fun building up your character + Character Design is well done and there are a great many models to chose from + Atmosphere/Artwork - Definitely won't win any graphic awards but this game really does transport you to this dystopian future + Music is perfect for the game  Cons - Plotline - It seems like the overall story was written by different teams and then pieced together at the end. There is no consistent flow from start to finish and while each individual piece is interesting, ultimately the sum of its part is actually less than each individually. - Replayability - This was one of the more frustrating aspects of the game. The mechanics are phenomenal but the slow start to the story means that you have to wade through a lot of garbage to replay. This is a shame because the core gameplay just begs for multiple playthroughs - Ran into a few bugs with the game but only one ever forced me to restart a game - Difficulty is a little sporadic. Most of the game was a breeze with the team I put together but there was one scene in particular (the cemetary) that I ended up replaying for almost 2 hours because my team kept getting slaughtered! I actually found this scene to be far harder then the end boss.

The bad: The graphics leave a bit to be desired -- the art is good and the textures and models are too, but there is a lot fo cut-and-paste when it comes to the animations. A lot of attack spells are literally recolored fireballs or lightning bolts. Likewise, the voice acting is so bare-bones it might as well not even be there.  The ugly: The game's biggest failing has definitely got to be the character building. The game is class-less and level-less, but it still encourages you to specialize to an uncomfortable degree. On top of that, some builds, like Decker, are so specialized that unless the campaign you're playing is specifically designed to acommodate them, you're seriously gimped. If you spend your EXP wrong you can end up pretty screwed down the line, and there is no way to go back and redistribute. Do yourself a favor and don't overwrite saves. I had to swallow my pride and dial down the difficulty setting to get past a mission right at the end of the first arc in the main campaign, 'Dead Man's Switch'.   Your call on this one, folks.

Shadowrun Returns was an astoundingly addictive game. As a long time of fan of tabletop RPGs this game provides all that traditional character customization that I desire in a game. Each race has an area where it will excel as a focus. By investing in skills you can open new dialogue options and earn extra rewards. You won’t always know what you are about to get into when you enter a new area. There are normally several ways to solve any particular problem. As a result, building a well balanced team is imperative to completing missions.   Players of games like XCOM: Enemy Unknown and other grid based tactics games will feel right at home during combat. Combat requires you to think carefully about your moves and one wrong click can get a character killed. However, the game is somewhat more forgiving as you can revive any fallen character in the middle of battle as long as you have the right item. Combat can be problematic at times because the chance of hit seems to have some hidden values that you aren’t told about. I have missed way too many 80% hit chances for that to be the correct number. The world design and art style are high quality for the price of the game and the music is great to listen to.   There were only three major problems I had with the game. First the save game system in the main campaign is unpleasant at time. The game will auto save every time you enter an area. The problem is that there are certain levels where you have to do a 2-5 minute dialogue conversation before you enter combat. If you’re main character dies in combat you have to start the entire area over again. That includes the dialogue segment. This game needs to have a way to quick save before you go into combat so you don’t have to do the same dialogue segment multiple times.  Second, in some of the combat segments I ran into problems where an enemy would be behind some piece of terrain. Even though I could make a shot I had to hunt for the few pixels where the enemy was visible in order to select them for an attack. I would love it if there was a drop down menu of enemies that you could use target attacks.  Third, it was very frustrating that you could control your teammates outside of combat for two reasons. First you couldn’t take any items that you find on a mission (outside of combat) and give then two your teammates. As a result, I had lots of health packs I wanted to give to teammates but had to send to stashed instead. Second the player controlled characters is the one responsible for opening doors and will be the one blasted when an ambush is triggered. I want to order my companion street samurai to open the door for me.  The main campaign will probably take between 12-16 hours. There is also an active steam community producing additional campaigns. I strongly recommend Shadowrun Returns to anyone who enjoys an RPG with some heavy strategy elements.  EDIT 3/8/2014:  After Finishing Dragonfall on hard mode, I am happy to say that the developers have fixed the few reservations I had about the base game. First and foremost: they have finally implemented a save game system. In the base game I became majorly frustrated with the way the fact that if you lost is a battle you would have to restart the area from the beginning, including any dialogue segments. The ability to save at will (outside of battle) is a major improvement from the base game. (Though I do have some concerns about the ethics of making such a game necessary feature DLC.)  Story wise, Dragonfall is an all new full length campaign. It is in fact longer than the base game. I beat base game story in about 14 hours, Dragonfall took about 20. I was a little disappointed that you couldn’t import your old character at first, but after a few hours I realized that rolling up a new character made the story feel like it can stand on its own. The campaign itself feels very reminiscent of the story of Dragon Age: Origins. After the initial two missions, the world opens up to you and you have much more choice in what order you want to do the quests in.   I only have a few reservations about Dragonfall. First, while playing on hard mode I found the AI’s strategy was to through everything against your character and completely ignore your squad mates. I suppose this comes down to personal preference but I for me this seems like a pretty week strategy, though it certainly does make the game more challenging. In addition, points two and three is original review are still problems.

The first time I heard of the Shadowrun roleplaying game (the tabletop rpg that is), I found the entire concept pretty silly. Cyberpunk with elves and dwarves? I mean, come on! A lot of people complain that this game plays like it was made ten years ago, and that it would've been a bad game even by those standards. I disagree with that notion. The game is based on the ever so versatile Unity engine. 3D character models act in front of 2Dish backgrounds, with the player overlooking everything from an isometric perspective. Personally I find it pretty neat. The background is drawn with a lot of attention to details and the character models show enough of the same to tell them apart and still look unique. Sure, it doesn't have the same graphical power as a triple-A game, but it doesn't need it either. For an indie game straight out of kickstarter, it looks more than good. Soundwise it has background music appropriate for the scenery, with a mix of upbeat and eerily haunting techno. The dialogues are not voiced, but simply text-based. Which is not a dealbreaker in my opinion. The biggest complaint people seem to have about SRR is that you can't save whenever you want. The game autosaves after every scene transition. Didn't bother me one bit. It actually made the entire action even more tense. But the developers have already announced a manual save feature for the upcoming DLC.  So, do I recommend Shadowrun Returns? Yes, I do.I recommend to those people who want an easy introduction into the setting. I recommend it to the fans of Shadowrun for it finally being a decent adaptation. And I recommend it to everybody else on the grounds that it is just that: a pretty good game.

Amazing   Growing up in 90s and one of my very first PC games was 'Fallout', you can imagine how excited I am when I received 'Shadowrun Returns' from my friend as a gift in Steam. This game is everything we ever loved about role playing turn based strategy PC game which we grow up with. Here is a quick review of 'Shadowrun Returns'   Graphics - 7/10  Simple yet richly detailed iso-metric view. Every background, every characters are so much detailed. Although, this type of graphics seems outdated in today 3D standards, it is very refreshing and enjoyable to look at the whole area, or looking at the amazing drawing of the character potriat.    Music - 6/10  Weak in overall. It does captures the environment of neo-futuristics sound but it could be improved. There is no memorable music or sound in the whole game except for the title music. Even so, everything is minimal.   Story - 8/10  This is what captures the player. The Story of Shadowrun Returns! Without spoiling anything - You start out alone in the apartment where you received a video call from your 'Best Buddy'. Turns out that its a dead video which is triggered when the person died. Now its up to you to uncover the bottom of your friend's murder (and receive $ in doing so). You will feel like you are reading a great noval and the story drives you keep playing the game one area after another.    Gameplay - 10/10  This is the heart of the 'Shadowrun Returns'. If you are fan of Turn Based strategy game like original 'Fallout', you will feel that this is everything you wished for in 'Fallout 3'. You will need a lot of strategy to think, move, shot, or get into cover. You use magic or gun or just plain melee to wack the heck out of enemy. You will have two action points as simple as that is. There is no calculation of how many action point you need to do something. You either move and shot or shot twice in one turn. All up to you. You will wish you want to have more encounters just to have a little more fan with gameplay before moving on with story line. On top of that, you have wide arrays of custormization for your characters - from choosing race to your profession. You gain karma points from making choices in game which can be used to upgrade your character skills.   Overall score - 8/10  Highly recommended to all hardcore player and fan of Turn Based Strategy games.  Pros: Great story, amazing gameplay, Awesome roleplaying turn based strategy game. Cons: No map, No stealing or fight with anyone, Music is weak.

A Short review of Shadowrun Returns I see a bit of confusion on the forum and want to give a honest review .  What is this game?   It looks like a isometric rpg but if you are expecting over the top (get it?) Loot and Character customization you might have to look elsewhere.   You may ask what's the appeal in this game?  well as soon as you play a few hours in the campaign you'll notice one thing , no voice overs and thats a key point that actually will indicate what the game is, even the main campaign could have been user generated.   THIS GAME IS A MEAN TO TELL STORIES MADE BY USERS BASED ON THE SHADOWRUN LORE   Yes if you do enjoy dialogue and interactive stories this game is for you.  Other things that you might like   The combat could use some tweaking but while it lacks the features of games like XCOM , it has its charms and your team in general has more of a personality than most, and It's fun hiring a team for each mission. (you only have a permanent character usually and you hire the rest of your team each mission).  The lore even if your not familiar with it its engaging and fun, the gritty reality of cyberpunk with all the fun and magic of fantasy.  Other things that you might NOT like   If you cannot immerse yourself in the lore/story the game can feel shallow. The combat might seem simplistic especially on lower difficulties. While the models have good amount of variety some of the portraits might not suit your taste.

Shadowrun Returns is a cRPG in the Baldur's Gate or Planescape Torment style, set in the Shadowrun universe. The turn based combat is perfect, and the storyline is quite good. Everything runs fluid and its all very fun to play. The character customization system is great, leading to what appears to be many different ways to play through the game. The game comes with an editor and supports Steam Workshop, so there is no dearth of content to download and play with. If any of that sounds remotely interesting to you I highly recommend checking this game out.  If I were to say something negative, I'd have to say that the graphics are simple and the animations basic. However, depite relative simplicity, the art style is fantastic and makes the Shadowrun universe real. Also understand that despite being relatively simple, the graphics are by no means poor. There is great detail in the world, and all the characters are distinct from one another. Nothing feels out of place, and the graphics never hinder the experience.  All-in-all I would highly recommend Shadowrun Returns

I'm surprised how divided people are on this game. At the very least, I would think that even if someone didn't like it, they could appreciate the storytelling and unique atmosphere and gameplay this game offers.  Granted, I can understand that the combat system is a straight clone of XCOM: EU, but the rest of the experience is diverse, immersive, and portrays a world with as much depth as any I've seen in a game. Bear in mind, I was not a fan of the early Shadowrun games at all. While I could appreciate the concept, I think the final product was a little too abitious for the time. But in our current genration, this game succeeeds at taking elements we've seen before many times, and putting a twist on them to make them feel fresh and engaging, and at the same time, familiar and comfortable. Like I said, there's some XCOM influence in there. But there's also a little bit of Baldur's Gate in there. There's a little bit of Mass Effect in there. There's a little bit of Fallout in there. There truly are some familiar elements to each aspect of Shadowrun Returns, and yet it still manages to place you in a world that feels fresh, and exciting. I can certainly tell that this game would not be for everyone... Specifically those who dont like to read large amounts of dialogue. But to someone who's read the desciptions and reviews, and feels on the fence about it, I can say it's definitely worth a shot. It surprised me how quickly it hooked me in.

Sad, but some features discredited this game for me. I've honestly tried because of my old love to the turn-based games, but my enthusiasm slowly disappeared through the game. Let's talk about them: - Autosaves only. It's especially sweet when you get some levels bugged - it's happening sometimes and you can't finish the stage because of broken trigger on events and the only way to pass - restart and play it again... - Unbelievable lack of freedom: poor interactivity of the world; mostly linear levels and quests; minimalistic/casual interface/character interactivity. I'm asked myself - what the hell? They've got such a nice and ALREADY COMPLETE universe for game, made a nice storyline, had a chance to look at the games close by genre and etc. What did they made? Experienced and long time RPG veterans might be disappointed as the combat is easy and uses a streamlined version of the Pen and Paper rules, the story while with good dialog for the most part, suffers from pacing issues and isn't going to blow the minds of any Shadowrun veteran. Lots of fun, but plenty of issues.  First the good:  * Rich world and great atmosphere.  * The combat is fun, though a bit repetitive. For an RPG, this game is on the short side, which is probably just the right length to prevent things from getting too repetitive.  * Good story. Some parts are amazing. Some parts are just OK. I think it averages out to good.  Now the bad:  * More than two years after release, there are still some glaring typos in plot necessary dialogues (such as extraneous words that clearly don't belong).  * Movement is often awkward and slow. After finishing an area, you'll stay in turn based combat mode; this kills a bit of the fun of exploring a floor you've cleared.  * Very linear. I found two side missions which were both very short.  * Terrible point-and-click targeting. I found myself walking past targets I meant to attack and unable to move to squares behind allies simply due to not being able to target the right square or creatures.  Overall, the good outweighs the bad. It's worth a play and will probably take you about 15 hours at a leisurely pace.

There are 3 games in the series which makes up for the fact that they are not huge games on their own. They are not small either and I will replay each (Dragonborn is brilliant in setting, I simply loved cyberpunk Berlin) but part of me wishes instead of 3 games they had made 1 massive game. Anyway, that is not what happened and what we got, I can't complain with at all.   At the price this is a steal for any RPG/turn based fan, and a no brainer on the steam sale. 4.2 outa' 5!

Simple mechanics and engaging story result in a superbly wonderful gameplay.  I played this game for a while. It was quite a slow start for me as it failed to hook me, but the mechanics were fun so I kept playing it. Before I knew it, I was completely invested in this game. I played this game straight through without switching to any other and it was a great play.  I am biased towards turn based strategies and the ones that are developed right are such a joy to play. Shadowrun Returns is not an exception. It is a wonderful experience for Linux. The balance between fun and difficulty is just about right and I have been through several battles where I thought I'd never make it. Surviving such levels always had me on the edge, the reward of the story as it unfolded was nice.   The steampunk story is intriguing. There are some technical issues pertaining to screen flicker mostly on splash screens but apart from that it is great. Lack of audio dialogue is also not a deal breaker.  I do not want to exaggerate about this game by saying it is a AAA - killer or anything. It is quite simple in it's implementation. However, what has been created is a wonderful game with good mechanics and a sound story.
